facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1426 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1426 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 16, 1968 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 908 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 16, 1968 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 908 of 1968.

facts.text: Appellant applied to the R.T.A. Coimbatore for a permit to ply a stage carriage on the route Bhavani to Vellithiruppur on August 8, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: On August 8, 1966, the appellant applied to the R.T.A. Coim- batore for a permit to ply a stage carriage on the route Bhavani to Vellithiruppur.

facts.text: The route Bhavani to Vellithiruppur was entirely a new route with no stage carriage plying on that route at that time.

anchor.surface_text: That was entirely a new route. No stage carriage was plying on that route at that time.

facts.text: The R.T.A. published the appellant's application under s. 57(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The R.T.A. published that application under s. 57 3  of the Act.

facts.text: Respondents Nos. 2-3 and others made representations against the application contending that there was no need to grant a stage carriage permit for that route.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents Nos. 2-3 and others made representations against that application companytending that there was numberneed to grant a stage carriage permit for that route.

facts.text: The R.T.A. overruled the objections and granted the permit on October 9, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The R.T.A. overruled their objection and granted the permit asked for on October 9, 1967.

facts.text: Some of the objectors appealed the R.T.A. order to the State Transport Appellate Tribunal, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: As against the order of the R.T.A. some of the objectors went up in appeal to the State Transport Appellate Tribunal, Madras.

facts.text: The Additional State Transport Appellate Tribunal allowed the appeal by its order dated February 22, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional State Transport Appellate Tribunal allowed the appeal by its order of February 22, 1968

facts.text: The Tribunal held that the R.T.A. failed to determine the question of the need for a service on that route before entertaining the application.

anchor.surface_text: holding that the procedure adopted by the T.A. was number in accordance with law inasmuch as it had failed to determine the question of the-need for a service in that route before entertaining the application for a stage carriage permit.

facts.text: The Tribunal held that the procedure adopted by the R.T.A. contravened s. 47(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the procedure adopted by the R.T.A. companytravened s. 47 3  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant challenged the Tribunal order in Writ Petition No. 908 of 1968 before the High Court of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged that order before the High Court of Madras in Writ Petition No. 908 of 1968.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed that application.

facts.text: The appeal to Supreme Court is by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: companysideration in this appeal by certificate.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1965 was decided by this Court on 27-10-1967.

anchor.surface_text: A. No. 95/65 decided on 27-10-1967.

facts.text: The judgment in Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1965 was delivered by this Court as M/s. Jaya Ram Motor Service v. S. Rajarathinam and ors.

concepts.unlisted_description: Mandates prior determination of number of permits

anchor.surface_text: Section 47 of the Act prescribes the procedure to be adopted by the R.T.A. in companysidering applications for stage carriage permit. That section reads A Regional Transport Authority shall, in companysidering an application for a stage carriage permit, have regard to the following matters namely  a  the interests of the public generally  b  the advantages to the public of the service to be provided, including the saving of time likely to be effected thereby and any companyvenience arising from journeys number being broken  c  the adequacy of other passenger transport services operating or likely to operate in the near future, whether by road or other means, between the, places to be served  d  the benefit to any particular locality or localities likely to be afforded by the service  e  the operation by the applicant of other transport services, including those in respect of which applications from him for permits-are pending  f  the companydition of the roads included in the proposed route or area and shall also take into companysideration any representations made by persons already providing passenger transport facilities by any means along or near the proposed route or area, or by any association representing persons interested in the provision of road transport facilities recognised in this behalf by the State Government, or by any local authority or police authority within whose jurisdiction any part of the proposed route or area lies Provided that other companyditions being equal, an application for a stage carriage permit from a companyoperative society registered or deemed to have been registered under any enactment in force for the time being shall, as far as may be given preference over applications from individual owners.

concepts.interpretation: Prescribes matters for R.T.A. consideration in granting stage carriage permits; sub-s.(3) for limiting number

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  of s. 47 of the Act required the Regional Transport Authority to limit the number of stage carriage permits that may be granted in a route having regard to the matters mentioned in sub-s.  1  of that section.

concepts.interpretation: Limit must be fixed anterior to entertaining individual applications to avoid manipulation and protect public interest

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: .  1 , limit the number of stage carriages generally or of any specified type for which stage carriage permits may be granted in the region or in any

anchor.surface_text: Section 57 3  reads On receipt of an application for a stage carriage permit or a public carriers permit, the Regional Transport Authority shall make the application available for inspection at the office of the Authority and shall publish the application or the substance thereof in the prescribed manner together with a numberice of the date before which representations in companynection therewith may be submitted and the date, number being less than 30 days from such publication, on which, and the time and place at which, the application and any representation received will be companysidered.

concepts.interpretation: Does not permit competing applications as representations; representations cannot be applications

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: position. The R.T.A. will have numberopportunity to choose between companypeting operators and hence public interest might suffer. Mr. Narsaraju, lear

anchor.surface_text: before granting a stage carriage permit two independent steps have to be taken. Firstly there should a determination by the R.T.A. under Sup./69-12 s.47 3 of the number of stage carriages for which stage carriage permits may be granted in that route.

concepts.interpretation: Two independent steps: first fix number under s.47(3), then entertain applications

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to s.57 3  lays down that if the grant of a permit has the effect of increasing the number of vehicles operating in that region or in any specified area thereof or on the route within such region beyond the limit fixed under s. 47  3 , the Authority may dismiss the application summarily.

concepts.interpretation: If grant exceeds s.47(3) limit, dismiss summarily

issues.text: whether the determination as to the number of stage carriages required on a route should be done at a stage anterior to that of entertaining applications for stage carriage permits or that it could be done at the time it considers applications made by operators for stage carriage permits in that route

anchor.surface_text: The question for determination is whether the determination as to the number of stage carriages required on a route should be done at a stage anterior to that of entertaining applications for stage carriage permits or that it could be done at the time it considers applic

issues.text: whether sub-s. 3 of s. 57 of the Act is wide enough to allow the competing operators to apply for the route in question when the first applicant's application is published and representations called for

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Narsaraju, learned Counsel for the appellant tried to meet the difficulty by suggesting that sub-s.  3  of s. 57 of the Act is wide enough to allow the competing operators to apply for the route in question when the first applicants application is published and representations called for.

issues.text: whether the procedure adopted by the R.T.A. contravened s. 47(3) of the Act by failing to determine the need for a service in that route before entertaining the application for a stage carriage permit

anchor.surface_text: holding that the procedure adopted by the T.A. was not in accordance with law inasmuch as it had failed to determine the question of the need for a service in that route before entertaining the application for a stage carriage permit. The Tribunal held that the procedure adopted by the R.T.A. contravened s. 47 3  of the Act.

issues.text: the scope of s. 47(3) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde, J. The scope of s. 47 3  of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1 939  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  comes up for consideration in this appeal by certificate. The facts of the case necessary for the purpose of deciding the point in issue are few,

arguments.claim: there was no need to grant a stage carriage permit for that route

anchor.surface_text: Respondents Nos. 2-3 and others made representations against that application contending that there was no need to grant a stage carriage permit for that route.

anchor.surface_text: holding that the procedure adopted by the T.A. was number in accordance with law inasmuch as it had failed to determine the question of the-need for a service in that route before entertaining the application for a stage carriage permit.

arguments.court_reasoning: ss.47 and 57 read together confirm anterior determination required

arguments.claim: the determination as to the number of stage carriages required on a route could be done at the time it considers applications made by operators for stage carriage permits in that route

anchor.surface_text: The R.T.A. has proceeded on the basis that question can be decided while considering the applications made to it for permits by operators whereas the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court have taken a contrary view.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r permits by operators whereas the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court have taken a companytrary view. Sub-s.  3  of s. 47 of the Act if read by its

arguments.court_reasoning: contrary to harmonious reading of ss.47 and 57

arguments.claim: sub-s. (3) of s. 57 of the Act is wide enough to allow the competing operators to apply for the route in question when the first applicant's application is published and representations called for

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Narsaraju, learned Counsel for the appellant tried to meet the difficulty by suggesting that sub-s.  3  of s. 57 of the Act is wide enough to allow the competing operators to apply for the route in question when the first applicants application is published and representations called for.

arguments.qualifiers: tried to meet the difficulty by suggesting

court_response_anchor.surface_text: position. The R.T.A. will have numberopportunity to choose between companypeting operators and hence public interest might suffer. Mr. Narsaraju, lear

arguments.court_reasoning: representations cannot take form of competing applications; would create unending chain of publications and objections

arguments.claim: if ss. 47 and 57 of the Act are read together, the determination as to the number of stage carriages must be done anterior to entertaining applications

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s.  3  of s. 47 of the Act if read by itself does number throw any light on the controversy before us but if ss. 47 and 57 of the Act are read together it appears to us to be clear that the view taken by the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court is the correct view.

arguments.claim: contrary view allowing determination at application stage opens door to manipulations, nepotism, and personality influencing decisions, harming public interest

anchor.surface_text: if companytrary view is taken it will throw open the door for manipulations and nepotism. There may be possibility of the personality of the applicant influencing the decision of the R.T.A. on the question of need for a stage carriage permit in the route and thereby public interest which should be the main consideration while taking a decision under s. 47 3  may suffer.

arguments.claim: accepting R.T.A. view places first applicant in commanding position, depriving R.T.A. of choice among competing operators, harming public interest

anchor.surface_text: If we accept the view taken by the R.T.A. as companyrect, an operator who happens to apply for the route first will be in a commanding position. The R.T.A. will have numberopportunity to choose between competing operators and hence public interest might suffer.

arguments.claim: before granting stage carriage permit, two independent steps required: first determination under s.47(3) of number of permits, then entertain applications

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the relevant provisions of the Act and the purpose behind ss. 47, and 57, we are companyvinced that before granting a stage carriage permit two independent steps have to be taken. Firstly there should a determination by the R.T.A. under s.47 3 of the number of stage carriages for which stage carriage permits may be granted in that route.

arguments.claim: above conclusion accords with view in Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1965 (M/s. Jaya Ram Motor Service v. S. Rajarathinam)

anchor.surface_text: Our above companyclusion accords with the view expressed by this Court in Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1965.  M s. Jaya Ram Motor Service v. S. Rajarathinam and ors.

holdings.text: if ss. 47 and 57 of the Act are read together it appears to us to be clear that the view taken by the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court is the correct view

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s.  3  of s. 47 of the Act if read by itself does number throw any light on the companytroversy before us but if ss. 47 and 57 of the Act are read together it appears to us to be clear that the view taken by the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court is the companyrect view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Sections 47 and 57 requires prior determination of permit numbers under s.47(3)

holdings.text: That sub-section merely permits representations to be made in respect of the application published. Such representations cannot take the form of competing applications

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Narsaraju, learned Counsel for the appellant tried to meet the difficulty by suggesting that sub-s.  3  of s. 57 of the Act is wide enough to allow the competing operators to apply for the route in question when the first applicants application is published and representations called for. We are unable to accept this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.57(3) limited to representations on published application, not new competing applications; otherwise leads to unending chain

holdings.text: before granting a stage carriage permit two independent steps have to be taken. Firstly there should a determination by the R.T.A. under s.47(3) of the number of stage carriages for which stage carriage permits may be granted in that route. Thereafter applications for stage carriage permits in that route should be entertained

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the relevant provisions of the Act and the purpose behind ss. 47, and 57, we are convinced that before granting a stage carriage permit two independent steps have to be taken. Firstly there should a determination by the R.T.A. under s.47 3 of the number of stage carriages for which stage carriage permits may be granted in that route.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of provisions and purpose of ss.47 and 57 mandates two-step process: fix limit first, then applications

holdings.text: The R.T.A. is not competent to grant stage carriage permits for more carriages than fixed under s.47(3)

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter applications for stage carriage permits in that route should be entertained. The R.T.A. is number competent to grant stage carnage permits for more carriages than fixed under s.47 3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limit under s.47(3) binding on subsequent grant of permits

holdings.text: Our above conclusion accords with the view expressed by this Court in Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1965, M/s. Jaya Ram Motor Service v. S. Rajarathinam and ors.

anchor.surface_text: Our above conclusion accords with the view expressed by this Court in Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1965.  M s. Jaya Ram Motor Service v. S. Rajarathinam and ors.   1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior Supreme Court precedent confirms the two-stage process under s.47

holdings.text: the procedure adopted by the R.T.A. contravened s. 47(3) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the procedure adopted by the R.T.A. contravened s. 47 3  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failure to determine need prior to entertaining application violates s.47(3); affirmed by court

precedents.cited_proposition: The Regional Transport Authority may modify the limit fixed under s.47(3), but once fixed, cannot ignore it while considering applications for permits under s.48.
